reviewText: There's always a bigger fish" sums up the whole game for those who don't want to read
date: now on to the review for those looking for a more in depth look.\n\nOkay
hoursPlayed: Tasty Blue sound familiar? Well if you ever heard of tasty planet way long ago then you'd know this is that game.\n\nThe first part I'll talk about is what is it? Well it's what it looks like a game where you eat things that you can until you grow enough so that you can eat bigger objects and then when you eat enough of those you can eat the evven bigger objects and so on. Your character will occasionally make these accented sounds like "yummy" "yum-yum" and everytime you finish a level he goes "oompa!" that's just the first character though but I'll get to that later. As far as the two predecessing games go
voteText: the sound assets are the same throughout with screaming people and animals and crunch noises when eating
helpfulPercent: as far as I know they haven't made any different sound clips. There is a local co-op that allows you to use the other controls. The controls are simple
votesHelpful: you either move with the mouse
votesTotal: the WSAD keys or arrow keys(the game won't mention the wsad keys but they works just fine)\n\nNow I think I've talked about the original titles enough now I shall discuss what makes this differ from the other games. For starters
votesFunny: it's based in the ocean so there's water physics and the ability to launch yourself out of the ocean. instead of it being 2D top down it's a sidescroller so it may look a bit off in some places. The story as far as I know is about as descriptive as any of the others and uneccesary at most. now the strange thing about this game is that there's no clear chapters anywhere
commentsCount: you know there's 3 different fish types but there's no clear definition where one starts or ends. Now how the fish work
column16: beign that you control a fish and not a grey blob
column17: you can generally move forward with better ease with a challenge for doing a 180 some people might not like this but the only real issue I found was when I tried to eat an object and I ended up looping around it for a bit before I had to turn off. The game seems to have a star scoring system involved
column18: there's a timer on the top right so if there's any obsessionalists who strife for completion the game has that. There's at least 5 difficulty setting that change the damage ratio on enemies.\nThe setting are simple but more than what the other two games had
column19: you got graphics with aspect ratio but everything else is just a checkbox. Something different they decided to do is include a "carnage" system where you use a slider to change how much "blood" shows when you eat something that's alive. Control options are bare minimum with only mouse sensitivity options
column20: with no rebindable keys.... could be an issue\n\nThat's about all I can think of for information
column21: I guess if you either played the original tasty planet games 10 years ago or are curious to play a katamari esqu title then this is your game
column22: it's not for everyone though clearly with visual quality not high in depth. At it's current price and estimated play time of about an hour or two it's definitely a fair price range. And even then if your not satisfied I'm certain this game will be on sale either with the weekly or seasonally.\n\nI really do reccomend this though

reviewText:
If you like Eat 'em up games, you will really like this one. From its great animation to its amusing music (Sometimes).

+ Very Fluid Animations
+ Nice Backgrounds
+ Addictive Gameplay
+ Great price!

- Not so great transitions into each level (Not really following on to the last events)
- Story would have been more entertaining if there were more of it.
- Gets a bit repetitive half way through the game.

I clocked 4 hours on this game (Not including the Bonus Levels). Found it best to play in small amounts which I am pretty sure it was designed for anyway. Would definitely play a sequel as this one was very addictive. For such a cheap price for a game that would normally go for a little more its not bad at all.

My opinion is if you are bored and want to play a casual game where you devour literally everything on the screen its a good past time. (Also turn on Carnage mode if you are interested in many blood puddles from your excessive chomping)

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sDIimELua-8

Tasy Blue is is a smaller arcade game, a mutant fish simulator with
cute graphics and entertaining gameplay.  It operates on a star system,
which encourages replayability, but I feel the game would have benefitted
from having a leaderboard.

Your objective is to eat smaller items or fish, and the more you eat,
the larger you grow.  The comedic aspects comes when you may find yourself
large enough to eat small boats or buildings within the missions.  The
mechanic is simple, but is solidly supported by the music, which helps
keep the atmosphere, and the level design, which mixes up the levels so
you don't feel like you are replaying the same mission with small variations.

This is a small, simple, game with solid mechanics and an entertaining
arcade feel.  I can easily recommend this for those that enjoy this
sort of game.

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here:
http:/www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText:
This is how I imagine Popcap would design a Katamari clone. It is fast, goofy, has often-questionable hit meshes, even-more-so questionable animal-to-world scales, and it's a lot of fun while it lasts. It is certainly no Katamari, nor shares the polish and budget of a Popcap title, but if you like a game that doesn't take itself seriously, you'll probably like this game.

The game is short - I finished in just over 2 hours. It is split into levels which chronicle the lives of three different aquatic animals as they grow to monster sizes. The game really shines when it drops you into a large body of water with a large variety and population of things to eat. This becomes very apparent as soon as you encounter the boring and frustrating oyster levels which there are two of. You'll know what I mean when you get there. There are also bonus levels at the end which offer some more fun after the campaign.

If you let yourself just steep in the ridiculousness of this title, you'll surely enjoy it while it lasts. Minor things like keyboard controls, repetitive (but often totally bangin') music, and those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ oyster levels might make you want to kill yourself briefly, but that's just a sign you've been playing this game for too long at a time. I finished my 2-hour playthrough in three sittings.

If you still want the game at this point, I wholeheartedly recommend it because it's downright fun for the price.

reviewText: Hilarious game, mostly suitable for children because it does get repetitive and it's rather mindless. You're a fish and you eat everything that moves in a level, starting with small fish and ending with fighter jets and naval boats. What makes the game really fun is the co-op. One player can use keyboard and player2 the mouse, or you can use two xbox 360 controllers like we did. You can turn splitscreen on or off, so that you have to stay together or not. The game has a blood effect when you eat something, that you can turn off as well if you think it's not appropriate.

reviewText:
This game is exactly like some free flash games I played when I was younger. They even use a lot of the same sound effects that they used from back then!

The main story is beaten in under 2 hours and the multiplayer has no right of existing because it is somehow trying to be both cooperative and competitive at the same time. In most of the levels during multiplayer one person can get all the available food that the other can eat, thus making the second player stuck being too small to be able to do anything.

Honestly you could play the flash games these developers have made instead of wasting your money with this. Sure, it's just 6 euro, but that's way more than I would pay for the amount of content it has.

reviewText:
Tasty Blue is a game with a pretty cool premise: You are a small sea creature working your way up the food chain by eating progressively larger sea creatures and gradually increasing your size. There have been many similar games to use this concept, dating at least as far back as the early 2000s with browser games on sites like Newgrounds, but Tasty Blue looks like the kind of game that would expand on it.

It doesn't.

Yes, there are a ton of levels, but there is very little variation among them. Combined with controls so slippery you feel like you're underwater yourself, the novelty wears off quickly.
Don't waste your money. You can play better games with the same concept on your browser for free.

reviewText:
Decided to buy this game because I used to play a game that's quite similar when I was a kid. It was a browser game, and it was about being a fish eating other fish to grow bigger to then it the bigger fish.

The thing is, that game was actually more fun than this one because there was actual difficulity. In Tasty Blue you only get set back a small amount of size when hit. You can't die which means there is no challenge.

Other than that, it has a nice art style with vibrant colours and a childish cartoonish style. The physics are also pretty cool I guess, and sometimes it feels quite satisfying to eat up a whole city as a goldfish. But other than that, it's really not good and I wouldn't reccomend it mainly because of the non-existant challenge.

reviewText:
Tasty Blue; Having completed this game in normal mode and tried all the bonus levels, I have a few things to say...

PROS:

-You get to be a number of cute aquatic characters that get the opportunity to eat or be eaten in the wild world of the great blue sea, which is fun.
-The music is quirky and light hearted
-There's a bit of a story (although I'll get to this in more detail)
-The gameplay over all is cute and cartoony, ideal for children.

CONS:

-Levels very repetitive in terms of what you can do/eat and your characters abilities.
-The story was promising to begin with. Three scenarios are lined up for you to experience; the goldfish that gets overfed and escapes their prison of a bowl, the opressed dolphin that makes their escape from the mediocrity of jumping through hoops for its human overlords entertainment and the genetically engineered shark that was created to defeat the other two monster characters, but decided it was still hungry afterwards. HOWEVER, I personally felt like there could have been a slightly more in depth story, which may have broken up the repetitiveness of each characters plights. However these story introductions leave me wanting to know about more of a follow up to the characters.
-Continuity issues: One level I've grown to the size of a house, and am EATING houses, the next, I'm back to the size of a tuna fish... why? I thought there was a linear story happening here...? Also, orcas that are half the size of helicopters.
-Same old ability: space to boost, space to boost, space to boost..... Shouldn't different creatures ahve different perks?

In conclusion; 'Feeding Frenzy' did it better. Seriously, if you're considering buying this game for your kids, sure, go for it, but if you like the mechanic of playing as a creature that must eat or be eaten, and consequently grow and eat bigger things, look up Feeding Frenzy. It's fantastic, and has a great story with a touch of mystery beautiful artwork, and each character has specific attributes and abilities.

Do I recommend this game?

For kids, sure, but go google Feeding Frenzy anyway.

reviewText:
Katamari Damacy meets Echo the Dolphin... a cliché way to describe a game, perhaps, but accurate nonetheless. Fortunately, it lacks both the stress-inducing time-limits of the former, and the obnoxious difficulty of the later. You're graded according to how quickly you get through the stages, so if you wanna three-star every level, you're gonna have to move your tail - but if you just wanna take it easy, enjoy the sights, and stop to eat the flowers, nothing's stopping you.

Of course, unless you DO want to do exactly that, it's going to be a fairly short game. Don't expact days of entertainment here - you can blast through the whole thing in an evening if you're so inclined. Still, it's a fair ammount of fun for the price, and worth owning just for the experience of going straight from chomping on zytoplankton to eating the moon within the space of a single game.

The only real critique I can level at it is that some of the levels have you hang around the same area, eating the same endlessly-respawning objects for way too long time - but that's ultimately a minor quibble. The controls are tight and responsive, particularly if you're using a controller, the physics are tuned more towards 'fun' than 'realism' (which is how it SHOULD be), and there's a huge variety of things to eat - from bottlecaps to aircraft-carriers. So if you're looking for an afternoon of anarchic, all-devouring fun, look no further than this clever little game!

reviewText: If you want a nice little time waster you could do a lot worse. This game executes the feeling of growing larger and larger in a Katamari Damacy sort of way really well. Its a shame some of the levels aren't more varied, but there is only so much you can do with a game based entirely underwater. My hope is if a sequel rolls around we'll see different animals with different abilities.

reviewText:
If you've ever played a Katamari game, this is basically the same idea put in a 2D setting. Not much in the way of challenge other than trying to clear a level as fast as possible. It is a fun distraction, but probably nothing that will keep you playing for long periods of time.

What this game lacks is visual appeal. The art style is cute and quirky, but the environments are rather bland and repetitive. The same can be said about the music. What is there is fitting and somewhat catchy, but it lacks variety and you'll get tired of hearing the menu/map music if you play it for too long.

Overall it is a decent game and worth playing if you catch it at a discounted price. Just don't expect a lot of depth even though you'll be diving deep to eat more and more.

Do I recommend this game? Well as you can see from my thumb, I definitely do...why?

Because it is fun in what it purposes, and it does it in many ways...like...do you want an enjoyable mindless eat them up game without any difficulty? reviewText:
Tasty Blue; Having completed this game in normal mode and tried all the bonus levels, I have a few things to say...

PROS:

-You get to be a number of cute aquatic characters that get the opportunity to eat or be eaten in the wild world of the great blue sea, which is fun.
-The music is quirky and light hearted
-There's a bit of a story (although I'll get to this in more detail)
-The gameplay over all is cute and cartoony, ideal for children.

CONS:

-Levels very repetitive in terms of what you can do/eat and your characters abilities.
-The story was promising to begin with. Three scenarios are lined up for you to experience; the goldfish that gets overfed and escapes their prison of a bowl, the opressed dolphin that makes their escape from the mediocrity of jumping through hoops for its human overlords entertainment and the genetically engineered shark that was created to defeat the other two monster characters, but decided it was still hungry afterwards. HOWEVER, I personally felt like there could have been a slightly more in depth story, which may have broken up the repetitiveness of each characters plights. However these story introductions leave me wanting to know about more of a follow up to the characters.
-Continuity issues: One level I've grown to the size of a house, and am EATING houses, the next, I'm back to the size of a tuna fish... why? I thought there was a linear story happening here...? Also, orcas that are half the size of helicopters.
-Same old ability: space to boost, space to boost, space to boost..... Shouldn't different creatures ahve different perks?

In conclusion; 'Feeding Frenzy' did it better. Seriously, if you're considering buying this game for your kids, sure, go for it, but if you like the mechanic of playing as a creature that must eat or be eaten, and consequently grow and eat bigger things, look up Feeding Frenzy. It's fantastic, and has a great story with a touch of mystery beautiful artwork, and each character has specific attributes and abilities.

Do I recommend this game?

For kids, sure, but go google Feeding Frenzy anyway.

I first saw this game from the game grumps playing a few levels, They were having such a blast and it was amusing to watch. So once i put some funds into steam I prchased the game and I was not disappointed.

Though the music is rather unfitting at times, seriously who has celtic music for a game about a fish that can go to 300 feet and devous everything in its path as it swims around leaving a path of destrction and agony on the marine life and any person caught on a boat?! reviewText:
This game is fun, it's like Pac Man without the maze...yeah. No seriously, play the game. Once you finish it you'll see what I mean.

The controls are pretty simple, you just direct your creature around with your mouse. Keep moving and eating things smaller than your creature and avoid things bigger than your creature. Your creature grows by eating things. Your creature must attain a certain size before completing the level.

Pretty simple and fun game.

reviewText: Is Tasty Blue a well made game? No, not by any stretch of the imagination. But what it lacks in design and control, it more than makes up for with pure unbridled fun. A sequel-ish to Tasty Planet, Tasty Blue shares much of its mechanics with its predecessor, but while Tasty Planet took place on a flat plane from a birds-eye view, Tasty Blue instead is treated like a diorama of sorts, meaning gravity has an effect on the game's physics. Tasty Blue certainly does not have the same charm as Tasty Planet did, given the fact that you're eating mostly fish and people, but the gameplay remains enjoyable enough to keep playing it. There are some issues I have with the game, such as its seemingly poor optimisation on my computer and tough to use controls, but those problems are washed away by the fact that I simply enjoy the game. Getting 3 stars on a level is often very hard, and sometimes RNG based, but trying to get as many stars as you can keeps me entertained enough to keep playing the same levels over and over.\n\nI would recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Tasty Planet, or Feeding Frenzy from way back in the day. While the game looks (and is) simple, that doesn't make it any less fun, and there is a certain childish whimsy to hearing that the sounds of eating accompanied by silly looking blood. If anything, this game brings me back to a simpler time when I first found sites like Big Fish Games and PopCap, and the ability to relive that odd nostalgia makes the purchase more than worth it.

reviewText:
Tasty Blue is a fun little game to just pick up and play to pass the time, and as the title suggests... It's nautical themed and you take control of three hungry aquatic creatures (The Dolphin being my personal favorite) as they each climb up the food chain to eventually dominate, and greedily consume everything they see. The optional carnage" visuals also add a nice touch when you're scarfing loads of helpless prey down your gullet and into your bottomless pit of a belly.

Pros-
Simple gameplay that's quick to learn
recommended: Lot's of creatures and objects to see (and eat)
voteText:
Adjustable carnage effects!

Cons-
Music tracks can feel repetitive after "very" long extended play (But it's pretty cute and fits the theme none the less)
helpfulPercent: Story is pretty short.\n\nIf you're feeling bored and in the mood to go on a massive eating spree in the ocean to pass the time
votesHelpful: then this simple little game is for you and you can't go wrong with a 6USD price."
